Award.AwardTitle: Enhancement of Spectrum Decision through Probabilistic Graphical Models
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research is increase the consumer's quality of service in environments where more and more services are competing for use of the radio spectrum. It is widely believed that future regulation of the spectrum will change from the current static environment, where opening new channels for communications takes years, to highly dynamic environment where smart radios will jump from frequency channel to frequency channel. In this dynamic environment, the consumer will share the spectrum with many different types of devices, including radars, other phones, Wi-Fi servers and a host of new smart devices.

The new smart devices will constantly change their frequencies, data rates and modulation schemes, thereby creating a dynamic, more uncertain, environment. The scientists will explore how uncertainty influences the characterization of radio spectrum usage. The focus is on the sensing and decision-making aspects of the problem rather than management issues. The scientists will apply their experience with Artificial Intelligence and transfer techniques of dynamic problem solving from other domains. The proposed study has the potential to develop decision support models that will inform new policies for spectrum management in the future.

This research project's primary aim is to advance the knowledge and understanding of wireless communication scenarios to enrich the spectrum decision process in cognitive radio by evaluating the impact of uncertainty on the different cognitive cycle changes of adaptive radios. To achieve this goal, they propose to identify, classify, and characterize the random and deterministic variables present in a typical wireless scenario and model their causal relations, using probabilistic graphical models, such as Bayesian networks and influence diagrams.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proliferation of wireless devices coupled with greatly increased demand for internet access and inefficient management of the radio spectrum have led to a spectrum shortage. In this project, we investigated how probabilistic models can mitigate these challenges and used these models to develop novel techniques to enable more dynamic and efficient access to the radio spectrum.

The project’s outcomes were broadly disseminated to the scientific community through 17 peer-reviewed journal articles and conference proceedings as well as 19 presentations at national and regional conferences. A total of 11 journal papers have been published/submitted of which 8 were published in high quality journals from publishers that include Elsevier, Wiley, IEEE, and MDPI. Additionally, 9 peer-reviewed proceedings have been published and presented at IEEE conferences, including the IEEE Wireless and Microwave Technology Conference, IEEE Computing and Communication Workshop and Conference, and the IEEE Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics & Mobile Communication Conference. The team also made 10 poster presentations at local and regional conferences including the Annual ND EPSCoR State Conference and the University of North Dakota Graduate Research Achievement Day (GRAD Day) for which 3 graduate students were selected as finalists from several hundred posters for the Best Poster Presentation Award. Moreover, information about the project and its outcomes were disseminated through a website established by the PI for the benefit of both the public and scientific community.

Graduate and undergraduate student training on cognitive radio is another important outcome. Ten graduate students and two undergraduate students were hired to work on the project, including eight Ph.D. and two MS candidates who were trained to conduct fundamental research in cognitive radio and improve their communication skills by writing research papers and presenting their findings in regional, national, and international conferences. Among these, two Ph.D. and two MS students have graduated between 2015 and 2018. Of the remaining students, two are in their final year while the rest have two years remaining before graduation. Other undergraduate students were also involved in the project through their senior design coursework.

As part of the project, the PI designed and taught a course titled “Sensing the radio spectrum” which served as an organizational framework for helping students understand concepts related to spectrum sensing techniques and their implementation using a combination of software defined radio systems and GNU Radio software. Five lab activities integrated into the course enabled students to better grasp the theoretical concepts learned in class. These lab activities were later shared with other international educators to use in their classes. Additionally, the PI integrated the project’s results in other courses.

Finally, the PI and her team developed and delivered outreach activities to expose students from different cultural and academic backgrounds to fundamentals of signal processing and wireless communications. To that end, several outreach activities targeting K-12, freshman engineering, and Indian-American students were conducted over the project timeline. An average of 50 students per year visited the PI’s research lab, Wireless Communications & Networking Laboratory, learning the basics of signal processing and wireless communications. In these activities, students wrote and modified MATLAB programs to process text and voice recordings by altering filter parameters and see how these signals are filtered and converted to physical signals before transmission. Additionally, students had the opportunity to become familiar with basic telecommunications principles including analog and digital signals, noise, frequency, modulation, and encoding techniques.
